abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Administration project's
            outcome is rated as satisfactory. The general lessons
            learned from this project include: 1) Important changes to
            the salary and employment structure require agreement from
            all stakeholders. 2) Accurate and transparent information
            needs to be provided on a regular basis to public servants
            when salary reforms are being undertaken to avoid creating
            false expectations that may later lead to frustrations and
            industrial actions. 3) When designing new salary regimes, it
            is important to obtain the most reliable information before
            embarking on the reform, to ensure that the new structure
            will be adequate to meet stated goals. Similarly, it is
            essential to carefully examine the effect of removing market
            supplements, in order to protect key and critical posts. 4)
            In exceptional circumstances, when Recruitment Programs are
            appropriate, it is important to ensure that the receiving
            departments are consulted as well as the concerned ministry,
            in order to maximize effectiveness and receptivity. 5) When
            dealing with issues such as decentralization, setting of
            tariffs, and the sorting out of the respective roles of
            various levels of government, it is important to hire
            consultants who are experts or nongovernmental organizations
            in some cases.

Guyana - Public Administration Project :
            Credit 2480 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Guyana - Public Administration
            Project : Credit 2480 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

18155028.theme: Public expenditure, financial management and procurement,Administrative and civil service reform

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will:  (1) facilitate
            adequate staffing of the public service, and eliminate
            staffing redundancies; (2) create conditions for
            accountability in financial and personnel management, as
            well as in fundamental public sector operational programs;
            and (3) support the preparation of a long-term strategy and
            program for public sector reform.  The project comprises the
            following three interrelated parts:  (a) reforming the
            public service salary and employment structure; (b) public
            sector management strengthening, including components on:
            (i) integrated financial management, (ii) the Regional
            Administrations systems, (iii) personnel management, and
            (iv) general administration; and (c) a recruitment program.
